sections.title: Design Habits That Support Wealth
sections.subtitle: Tie your values to daily routines so good money behavior becomes automatic

sections.title: You'll Practice
items: Linking habits to identity and values
Building cue-based systems for saving and budgeting

sections.title: Habit Science Essentials
sections.content: Financial habits stick when they are small, consistent, and tied to who you believe you are. Every repetition reinforces the identity of being responsible, generous, or growth-minded with money.

points.title: Cue
points.description: The trigger that tells your brain to start the routine (payday, morning coffee).

points.title: Routine
points.description: The behavior itself—checking accounts, logging expenses, transferring to savings.

points.title: Reward
points.description: The satisfaction or celebration that reinforces repeating the habit.

sections.title: Two-Minute Rule
sections.content: Shrink every new habit to an action you can complete in under two minutes to guarantee follow-through.

sections.title: Make Good Habits Easy
sections.content: Automate transfers, schedule calendar blocks, and use templates so your system handles routine money tasks. Meanwhile, add friction to spending habits—delete saved cards from shopping apps, or require a 24-hour wait before non-essential purchases.

sections.title: Habit Architecture
steps: Choose three money habits you want to strengthen (saving, reviewing statements, planning meals).
Define the cue, routine, and reward for each habit. Write it down in a tracker.
Reduce each habit to a simple two-minute version you can always complete.
Identify one habit to add friction to—remove the app, add a spending approval step, or require a waiting period.
Track your completion for 21 days, checking off each repetition to build momentum.

sections.title: Stack Habits
sections.content: Attach a new financial habit to something you already do daily—like reviewing accounts right after brushing your teeth at night.
